instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight
threads.message:
Got this with broken backlight. 12.3V on backlight. Replaced <CHIP>U7700</CHIP> and <TRANSISTOR>Q7701</TRANSISTOR> and I now have 52V on backlight output but still no backlight.
I have reset the PRAM but still no luck. I have also tested with a 2013 LCD but still the same.
Am I looking at a bad LCD screen here?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight
threads.message: 52V means open circuit to the LCD. Bad connector/cable/LCD. I bet someone fucked up pin 1 on the cable....

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight
threads.message: Ok, it was fucked but I have replaced the cable and connector on the logic board. Replaced with a 2013/2014 cable

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight
threads.message: No idea if they are the same. Measure if backlight pin has continuity at the LCD side.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight
[SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight
threads.message: Just an update, once again Duke you are right, it was the cable.
